question: Should religious freedom abroad be one of the primary foreign policy concerns for any country?

content.source_1: Brian J. Grim and Roger Finke, The Price of Freedom Denied: Religious Persecution and Conflict in the Twenty-First Century, Cambridge University Press (2011). Finding: Cross-national data show that higher government restrictions on religion and social hostilities are correlated with greater religious persecution and violence, implying that promoting religious freedom abroad can advance stability and security interests. https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/price-of-freedom-denied/2C1D0F6E4B2A9B7E1A9E9F6F7D0A6B3E
content.source_2: UN Human Rights Committee, General Comment No. 22 on Article 18 (Freedom of Thought, Conscience or Religion), interpreting the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (1993). Argument: States have a binding obligation under international law to respect and protect freedom of religion or belief, providing a normative basis for making it a primary foreign policy concern. https://www.ohchr.org/en/interpretive-guides/general-comment-no-22
content.source_3: International Religious Freedom or Belief Alliance (IRFBA), Joint Statements and Membership (launched 2020). Evidence: Dozens of countries have formed a dedicated alliance to prioritize and coordinate diplomacy on freedom of religion or belief, suggesting growing multilateral recognition that elevating this issue can enhance soft power and coalition-building. https://www.gov.uk/government/news/international-religious-freedom-or-belief-alliance-launched
content.source_4: Elizabeth Shakman Hurd, Beyond Religious Freedom: The New Global Politics of Religion, Princeton University Press (2015). Critique: Making “religion” a focal lens of foreign policy can misdiagnose local dynamics, empower select religious gatekeepers, marginalize dissenting minorities, and inadvertently intensify sectarian divides—reasons to be cautious about prioritizing it above other concerns. https://press.princeton.edu/books/hardcover/9780691166096/beyond-religious-freedom
content.source_5: Gary Clyde Hufbauer, Jeffrey J. Schott, Kimberly Ann Elliott, and Barbara Oegg, Economic Sanctions Reconsidered (3rd ed.), Peterson Institute for International Economics (2007). Finding: Sanctions—often the go-to tool for pressing human rights and religious freedom abroad—succeed only in a minority of cases and can impose significant humanitarian and diplomatic costs, questioning the practicality of making this a primary policy driver. https://www.piie.com/bookstore/economic-sanctions-reconsidered-3rd-edition
content.source_6: Henry Kissinger, World Order, Penguin Press (2014). Argument: Durable foreign policy prioritizes geopolitical stability and balance of power; elevating normative agendas like religious freedom to primary status can undermine order, strain alliances, and conflict with core security and economic interests. https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/235070/world-order-by-henry-kissinger/
